sp.p: You must do more then hear 'em▪ you know you were now going to your Bridal Bed. Call your own thoughts but to a strict account, they'l tell you all this day, your fancy ran on nothing else; 'tis but the same Scene still you were to act; only the person chang'd, it may be for the better.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: You dare not, sure, attempt this villany.

sp.speaker: Harm. Iun.
sp.p: Call not the act of Love by that grosse name, You'l give it a much better when 'tis done; and wooe me to a second.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Dost thou not fear a Heaven!

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: No, I hope one in you. Do it, and do it heartily; time is precious; it will prepare you better for your Husband.— Come. Lays hold on her.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Oh Mercy, Mercy, Oh pitty your own Soul, and pitty mine: think how you'l wish undone this horrid act when your hot Lust is slak'd: think what will follow when my Husband knows it, if shame will let me live to tell it him; and tremble at a power above, who sees, and surely will revenge it.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: I have thought!

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Then I am sure you're penitent.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: No, I only gave you scope to let you see all you have urg'd I knew: you find 'tis to no purpose either to talk or strive.

sp.speaker: Ysabinda
sp.p: running. Some succor, help, oh help.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: running after her. That too is vain, you cannot scape me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: within. Now you are mine; yield, or by force I'le take it.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: within. Oh kill me first.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: within. I'le bear you where your crys shall not be heard.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: as farther off. Succor sweet Heaven, oh succor me.

div.stage: Enter Harman Senior, Fiscal, Van Herring, Beamont, Collins, Julia.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: You have led us here a Fairies round in the Moon-shine, to seek a Bridegroom in a Wood, till we have lost the Bride.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I wonder what's become of her?

sp.speaker: Harm. Sen.
sp.p: Got together, got together I warrant you, before this time; you Englishmen are so hot, you cannot stay for Ceremonies, a good honest Dutchman wou'd have been plying the Glass all this while, and drunk to the hopes of Hans in Kelder till 'twas Bed-time.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Yes, and then have rowl'd into the sheets, and turn'd o'th' t'other side to snore, without so much as a parting blow; till about midnight he wou'd have waken'd in a maze, and found first he was Married by putting forth a Foot and feeling a Woman by him; and it may be then in stead of kissing, desir'd yough Fro to hold his head.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: And by that nights work have given her a Proofe what she might expect for ever after.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: In my Conscience you Hollanders never get your Children, but in the Spirit of Brandee; you are exalted then a little above your Natural Phlegm, and only that which can make you fight and destroy Men, makes you get 'em.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: You may live to know, that we can kill Men when we are sober.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Then they must be drunk, and not able to defend themselves.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Pray leave this talke, and let us try if we can surprize the Lovers under some convenient tree: shall we separate and look them?

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Let you and I go together then, and if we cannot find them, we shall do as good, for we shall find one another.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Pray take that path, or that, I will pursue this.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: So, now I have diverted them from Harman: I'le look for him my self; and see how he speeds in his adventure.

sp.speaker: Harm. Jun.
sp.p: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: A Friend: I was just in quest of you, so are all the Company: Where have you left the Bride?

sp.speaker: Har. Jun.
sp.p: Ty'd to a Tree and Gagg'd, and—

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: And what? Why do you stare and tremble? answer me like a man.

sp.speaker: Har. Jun.
sp.p: Oh, I have nothing left of Manhood in me; I am turn'd Beast or Devil; Have I not Hornes, and Tayle, and Leathern wings? methinks I shou'd have by my Actions— Oh I have done a Deed so ill, I cannot name it.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Not name it, and yet do it? that's a Fools Modesty: Come, I'le name it for you: You have enjoy'd your Mistriss?

sp.speaker: Har. Jun.
sp.p: How easily so great a Villany comes from thy mouth! I have done worse, I have ravish'd her.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: That's no harm, so you have kill'd her afterwards.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Kill'd her! Why thou art a worse Fiend then I.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Those Fits of Conscience in another might be excusable; but, in you, a Dutchman, who are of a Race that are born Rebels, and live every where on Rapine; Wou'd you degenerate, and have remorse? Pray what makes any thing a sin but Law; and, What Law is there here against it? Is not your Father Chief? Will he condemn you for a petty Rape? The Woman an Amboyner, and what's less, now Marry'd to an Englishman: Come, if there be a Hell, 'tis but for those that sin in Europe, not for us in Asia; Heathens have no Hell. Tell me, How was't? Prithee the History.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p:
I forc'd her— What resistance She cou'd
make she did, but 'twas in vain; I bound her as I told you to a tree:

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: And she exclaim'd I warrant—

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Yes, and call'd Heaven and Earth to witness.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Not after it was done.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: More then before— Desir'd me to have kill'd her. Even when I had not left her power to speak, she curst me with her eyes.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Nay, then, you did not please her; if you had she ne're had curs'd you heartily; but, we lose time: since you have done this action, 'tis necessary you proceed; we must have no tales told.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: To dispatch her immediately; Cou'd you be so senceless to ravish her, and let her live? What if her Husband shou'd have found her? What if any other English? Come there's no dallying; It must be done: My other plot is ripe, which shall destroy 'em all to morrow.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: I love her still to Madness, and never can consent to have her kill'd, wee'l thence remove her if you please, and keep her safe till your intended Plot shall take effect; And, when her Husband's gone, I'le win her Love by every circumstance of kindness.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: You may do so; but, t'other is the safer way: but I'le not stand with you for one life. I cou'd have wish'd that Towerson had been kill'd before I had proceeded to my plot; but since it cannot be, we must go on; Conduct me where you left her.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Oh that I cou'd forget both Act and Place.

div.head: Scene Drawn discovers Ysabinda bound

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Sure I mistook the place, I'le waite no longer, something within me does forebode me ill; I stumbled when I enter'd first this Wood: My Nostrills bled three drops: then stop'd the Blood, and not one more wou'd follow. What's that which seems to bear a Mortal Sees Ysabinda. shape, yet neither stirs nor speaks! or, Is it some Illusion of the Night? some Spectre, such as in these Asian parts more Frequently appear; What e're it be I'le venture to approach it; My Ysabinda Bound and Gagg'd! Ye Powers Goes near. I tremble while I free her, and scarce dare restore her liberty of Speech for fear of knowing more.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: No longer Bridegroom thou, nor I a Bride; those names are vanish'd; Love is now no more; Look on me as thou wou'dst on some foul Leaper; and do not touch me: I am all polluted, all shame, all o're dishonour; fly my sight, and, for my sake, fly this detested Isle, where horrid Ills so black and fatal dwell, as Indians cou'd not guess, till Europe taught.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Speak plainer, I am recollected now: I know I am a Man, the sport of fate; Yet, Oh my better half, had Heaven so pleas'd, I had been more content, to suffer in my self then thee.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: What shall I say! That Monster of a Man, Harman; now I have nam'd him, think the rest. Alone, and singl'd like a tim'rous Hind from the full Herd, by flattery drew me first, then forc'd me to an Act, so base and Brutall, Heaven knows my Innocence: but, Why do I call that to Witness! Heaven saw, stood silent: Not one flash of Lightning shot from the Conscious Firmament to shew its Justice: Oh had it struck us both, it had sav'd me!

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Heaven suffer'd more in that then you, or I: Wherefore have I been faithful to my trust, true to my Love, and tender to th' opprest? Am I condemn'd to be the second man, who e'r complain'd, he vertue serv'd in vain? But dry your tears, these sufferings all are mine. Your breast is white, and cold as falling Snow. You still as fragrant as your Eastern Groves; and your whole frame as innocent, and holy, as if your being were all soul and spirit, without the gross allay of flesh and bloud. Come to my arms again.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Oh never, never, I am not worthy now; My soul indeed is free from sin, but the foul speckled stains are from my body ne'r to be wash'd out, but in my death. Kill me, my Love, or I must kill my self; else you may think I was a black Adulteress in my mind, and some of me consented.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Your wish to die, shews you deserve to live. I have proclam'd you guiltless to my self. Self-homicide, which was in Heathens honour, in us is onely sin.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: I thought th' Eternal Mind had made us Masters of these mortal frames; you told me he had given us wills to choose, and reason to direct us in our choice; if so, why should he tie us up from dying, when death's the greater good?

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Can death, which is our greatest enemy, be good? Death is the dissolution of our nature; and nature therefore does abhor it most, whose greatest Law is to preserve our beings.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: I grant, it is its great general Law: But as Kings, who are, or should be above Laws, dispence with 'em when levell'd at themselves; Even so may man, without offence to Heaven, dispence with what concerns himself alone: Nor is death in it self an ill; then holy Martyrs sin'd, who ran uncall'd to snatch their Martyrdom: And blessed Virgins, whom you celebrate for voluntary death, to free themselves from that which I have suffer'd.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: They did it to prevent what might ensue; your shame's already past.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: It may return, if I am yet so mean to live a little longer.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: You know not, Heaven may give you succour yet; you see it sends me to you.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: 'Tis too late, you shou'd have come before.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Yet you may live to see your self reveng'd. Come you shall stay for that, then I'le die with you. You have convinc'd my reason, nor am I asham'd to learn from you. To Heavens Tribunal my appeal I make; if as a Governor he sets me here, to guard this weak built Cittadel of Life, when 'tis no longer to be held, I may with honour quit the Fort. But first I'll both revenge my self and you.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Alas, you cannot take revenge, your Countreymen are few, and those unarm'd.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Though not on all the Nation, as I wou'd; yet I at least can take it on the man.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Leave me to Heaven's revenge, for thither I will go, and plead my self my own just cause. There's not an injur'd Saint of all my Sex, but kindly will conduct me to my Judge, and help me tell my story.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: I'l send th'offender first, though to that place he never can arrive: ten thousand Devils damn'd for less crimes then he, and Tarquin in their head, way-lay his Soul, to, pull him down in triumph, and to shew him in pomp among his Countrey-men; for sure Hell has its Nether-lands, and its lowest Countrey must be their lot.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: 'Twas hereabout I left her ty'd. The rage of Love renews again within me.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: She'l like th'effects on't better now. By this time it has sunk into her imagination, and given her a more pleasing Idea of the man, who offer'd her so sweet a violence.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Save me, sweet Heaven, the Monster comes again.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Oh here she is: My own fair Bride, for so you are, not Towerson's: Let me unbind you; I expect that you should bind your self about me now, and tie me in your arms.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p:
[drawing] No, Villain, no; hot Satyr of the Woods! Expect another entertainment now. Behold revenge for injur'd
chastity, this Sword Heaven draws against thee, and here has plac'd me like a fiery Cherub, to guard this Paradice from any second Violation.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: We must dispatch him, Sir, we have the odds; and when he is kill'd, leave me to invent the excuse.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Hold a little: As you shun'd fighting formerly with me, so wou'd I now with you. The mischiefs I have done are past recall. Yield then your useless right in her I love, since the possession is no longer yours; so is your Honour safe, and so is hers, the Husband onely alter'd.

sp.speaker: Towers
sp.p: Ye trifle, there's no room for treaty here: The shame's too open, and the wrong too great. Now all the Saints in Heaven look down to see the Justice I shall do, for 'tis their cause; and all the Fiends below prepare thy Tortures.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: If Towerson wou'd, think'st thou my soul so poor to own thy sin, and make the base act mine, by choosing him who did it? Know, bad man, I'l die with him, but never live with thee.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Prepare, I shall suspect you stay for further help, and think not this enough.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: We are ready for you.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Stand back, I'l fight with him alone.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Thank you for that; so if he kills you, I shall have him single upon me.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Heaven assist my Love.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: There, Englishman, 'twas meant well to thy heart.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Oh you can bleed, I see, for all your cause.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Wounds but awaken English courages.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Yet yield me Ysabinda, and besafe.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: I'l fight my self all scarlet o'r first; were there no love, or no revenge, I cou'd not now desist in point of honour.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Resolve me first one question, Did you not draw your sword this night before, to rescue one opprest with odds?

sp.speaker: Towers
sp.p: Yes, in this very Wood: I bear a Ring, the badge of gratitude from him I sav'd.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: That Ring was mine; I shou'd be loth to kill the frank redeemer of my life.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: I quit that obligation. But we lose time. Come, Ravisher.

div.stage: They fight again, Towerson closes with Harman and gets him down; as he is going to kill him, the Fiscal gets over him.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Hold, and let him rise; for if you kill him, at the same instant you die too.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Dog, do thy worst, for I would so be kill'd; I'l carry his soul captive with me into the other world.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Oh mercy, mercy, Heaven. dies.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Take this then in return.

div.stage: As he's going to stab him, Ysabinda takes hold of his hand.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Hold, hold, the weak may give some help.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: (rising) Now, Sir, I am for you.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: (retiring) Hold, Sir, there is no more resistance made, I beg you by the honour of your Nation, do not pursue my life, I tender you my sword.

div.stage: Holds his sword by the point to him.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Base beyond example of any Countrey, but thy own.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Kill him, sweet Love, or we shall both repent it.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: (kneeling to her) Divinest Beauty! abstract of all that's excellent in Woman, can you be friend to murder?

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: 'Tis none to kill a Villain, and a Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: (kneeling to Towers.) Noble Englishman, give me my life, unworthy of your taking. By all that's good and holy here I swear, before the Governour to plead your cause; and to declare his son's detested crime, so to secure your lives.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Rise, take thy life, though I can scarce believe thee; if for a coward it be possible, become an honest man.

div.stage: Enter Harman senior, Van Herring, Beamont, Collins, Julia, the Governors Guard.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: to Harm. Oh Sir, you come in time to rescue me; the greatest Villain who this day draws breath stands here before your Eies; behold your Son, that Worthy, Sweet; unfortunate young Man lies there, the last cold breath yet hovering betwixt his trembling Lips.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Oh Monster of Ingratitude!

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Oh my unfortunate old age, whose prop, and only staff is gone, dead e're I dye, these shou'd have been his tears, and I have been that Body to be mourn'd.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: I am so much amaz'd, I scarce believe my Senses.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: And will you let him live, who did this Act? shall Murder, and of your own Son, and such a Son go free? he lives too long by this one Minute which he stays behind him.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Oh Sir, remember, in that place you hold, you are a common Father to us all; we beg but justice of you; hearken first to my lamented story.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: First hear me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Towers
sp.p: Thee slave, thou liv'st but by the breath I gave thee, didst thou but now plead on thy knees for life? and offer'dst to make known my innocence in Harman's injuries.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: I offer'd to have clear'd thy innocence who basely murder'd him? but words are needless; Sir, you see evidence before your eies, and I the witness, on my oath to Heaven how clear your Son, how criminal this Man.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Towerson cou'd do nothing but what was noble.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: We know his Native worth.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: His Worth? behold it on the Murderers hand, a Robber first, he took degrees in mischief, and grew to what he is: know you that Diamond, and whose it was? see if he dares deny't?

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Sir, 'twas your Sons, that freely I acknowledge; but how I came by it—

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: No, 'tis too much, I'le hear no more.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: The Devil of Jealousie, and that of Avarice, both I believe possest him; or your Son was innocently talking with his Wife, and he perhaps had found 'em; this I guess, but saw it not, because I came too late, I onely view'd the sweet Youth, just expiring, and Towerson stooping down to take the Ring: she kneeling by to help him; when he saw me, he wou'd, you may be sure have sent me after, because I was a witness of the fact; this on my Soul is true.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: False as that soul, each Word, each Syllable; the Ring he put upon my hand this night, when in this Wood unknown, and near this place, without my timely help he had been slain.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: See this unlikely story, what enemies had he who shou'd assault him, or is it probable that very Man who actually did kill him afterwards, shou'd save his life so little time before.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Base Man thou know'st the reason of his death; he had committed on my Person Sir an impious Rape; first ty'd me to that tree, and there my Husband found me, whose revenge was such, as Heaven and Earth will justify.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: I know not what Heaven will, but Earth shall not.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Her story carries such a face of Truth, ye cannot but believe it.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: The other a malicious ill-patch'd lye.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Yes, you are proper Judges of his crime, who with the rest of your Accomplices, your Countrey-men, and Towerson the chief, whom we too kindly us'd, wou'd have surpriz'd, the Fort, and made us Slaves; that shall be prov'd, more soon then you imagine; I found it out this evening.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Sure the Devil has lent thee all his stock of falshood, and must be forc'd hereafter to tell truth.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis impossible you shou'd believe it.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Seize 'em all.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: You cannot be so base.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: I'le be so just till I can hear your plea against this plot, which if not prov'd, and fully, you are quit, mean time, resistance is but vain.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Provided that we may have equal hearing, I am content to yield, though I declare, you have no power to judge us. Gives his sword.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Barb'rous ungrateful Dutch.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: See 'em convey'd apart to several prisons, least they combine to forge some specious Lye in their excuse, let Towerson and that Woman too be parted.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Was ever such a sad divorce made on a Bridal night! but we before were parted ne'r to meet, farewel, farewel, my last and only Love.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Curse on my fond credulity, to think there cou'd be Faith or Honor in the Dutch: Farewel my Ysabinda, and farewel my much wrong'd Countrey-men; remember yet that no unmanly weakness in your sufferings disgrace the Native Honour of our Isle;
sp.l: For you I mourn; grief for my self were vain,
I have lost all, and now wou'd lose my pain.

div.head: SCENE I. A Table set out.
div.stage: Enter Harman, Fiscal, Van Herring, and two Dutchmen they sit, Boy, and waiters, Guards.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: MY sorow cannot be so soon digested for losing of a Son I lov'd so well, but I consider, great advantages must with some loss be bought▪ as this rich Trade which I this day have purchas'd with his death, yet let me be reveng'd, and I shall still live on, and eat, and drink down all my griefs. Now to the matter, Fiscal.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p:
Since we may freely speak among our selves, all I have said of Towerson was most false; you were consenting,
Sir, as well as I, that Perez shou'd be hir'd to murder him, which he refusing when he was engag'd, 'tis dangerous to let him longer live.

sp.speaker: Van Her.
sp.p: Dispatch him, he will be a shrowd witness against us, if he return to Europe.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: I have thought better, if you please, to kill him by form of Law, as accessary to the English plot, which I have long been forging.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Send one to seize him straite. Exit a Messenger. But what you said, that Towerson was guiltless of my Sons death; I easily believe; and ne're thought otherwise, though I dissembl'd.

sp.speaker: Van Her.
sp.p: Nor I; but 'twas well done to feign that story.

sp.speaker: 1. Dutch.
sp.p: The true one was too foul.

sp.speaker: 2. Dutch.
sp.p: And afterwards to draw the English off from his concernment, to their own, I think 'twas rarely manag'd that.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: So far, 'twas well; now to proceed, for I would gladly know whether the grounds are plausible enough of this pretended plot.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: With favour of this Houourable Court, give me but leave to smooth the way before you. Some two or three nights since, (it matters not;) a Iapan Soldier under Captain Perez came to a Sentinel upon the Guard, and in familiar talk did question him about this Castle, of its strength; and how he thought it might be taken; this discourse the other told me early the next morning: I thereupon did issue private order, to wrack the Iaponnese, my self being present.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: But what's this to the English?

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: You shall hear, I ask'd him when his pains were strongest on him, if Towerson, or the English Factory, had never hir'd him to betray the Fort, he answer'd, (as 'twas true) they never had: nor was his meaning more in that discourse then as a Soldier to inform himself, and so to pass the time.

sp.speaker: Van Her.
sp.p: Did he confess no more?

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p:
You interrupt me, I told him I was certainly inform'd the English had designs upon the Castle, and if he franckly wou'd confess their Plot, he shou'd not only be Releas'd
from Torment, but bounteously rewarded: present pain and future hopes, in fine so wrought upon him, he yielded to subscribe what e'r I pleas'd; and so he stands committed.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Well contriv'd, a fair way made upon this accusation, to put them all to Torture.

sp.speaker: 2 Dutch.
sp.p: By his confession, all of 'em shall dye, ev'n to their General Towerson.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: He stands convicted of another Crime, for which he is to suffer.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: This do's well, to help it though. For Towerson is here a Person publickly Employ'd from England, and if he shou'd appeal, as sure he will, you have no power to Judge him in Amboyna.

sp.speaker: Van Her.
sp.p: But in regard of the late League and Union, betwixt the Nations, how can this be answer'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Dutch:
sp.p: To Torture Subjects to so great a King, a pain ne'er heard of in their happy Land, will sound but ill in Europe.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Their English Laws, in England have their force; and we have ours, different from theirs; at home; It is enough, they either shall confess; or we will falsity their hands to make e'm; then for th' Apologie let me alone; I have it writ already to a Tittle, of what they shall subscribe; this I will publish, and make our most unheard of Cruelties, to seem most just, and legal.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Then in the name of him, who put it first into thy Head to form this damn'd false Plot, proceed we to the Execution of it; and to begin; first seize we their Effects, Rifle their Chests, their Boxes, Writings, Books, and take of e'm a seeming Inventory; but all to our own use; I shall grow young with thought of this, and lose my Sons remembrance.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Will you not please to call the Prisoners in? at least inquire, what Torments have extorted.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Go thou and bring us word▪ Exit Fiscal.
Boy, give me some Tobacco, and a stope of Wine, Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: I shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And a Tub to leak in Boy; when was this Table without a leaking Vessel.

sp.speaker: Van. Her.
sp.p: That's an Omission.

sp.speaker: 1 Dutch:
sp.p: A great Omission.
'Tis a Member of the Table, I take it so.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Never any thing of Moment was done at our Counsel Table, without a leaking Tub; at least in my time; great affairs require great Consultations, great Consultations require great Drinking, and great Drinking a great leaking Vessel.

sp.speaker: Van Her.
sp.p: I am e'en drunk with joy already, to see our godly business in this forwardness.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Where are the Prisoners?

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: At the door,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Bring e'm in; I'le try if we can face e'm down by Impudence, and make e'm to confess.

You are not ignorant of our Business with you; the cryes of your Accomplices already have reach'd your Ears; and your own Consciences, above a thousand Summons, thousand Tortures instruct you what to do. No farther Juglings, nothing but plain sincerity and truth to be delivered now; a free confession, will first attone for all your sins above; and may do much below to gain your Pardons, let me exhort you therefore, be you merciful, first to your selves, and make acknowledgement of your Conspiracy?

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: What Conspiracy.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Why la you, that the Devil shou'd go Mask'd with such a seeming honest face; I warrant you know of no such thing.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Were not you Mr. Beamont, and you Collins both accessary to the horrid Plot, for the Surprisal of this Fort and Island.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: As I shall reconcile my Sins to Heaven, in my last Article of Life, I'm innocent.

sp.speaker: Collins:
sp.p: And so am I.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: So, you are first upon the Negative.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: And will be so till death.

sp.speaker: Collins:
sp.p: What Plot is this you speak of?

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Here are Impudent Rogues, now after confession of two Japonneses, these English Starts dare ask what Plot it is.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Not to enforme your knowledge, but that Law may have its course in every circumstance; Fiscal, sum up their accusation to e'm.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: You stand accus'd, that New years day late past, there met at Captain Towerson's House, you present, and many others of your Factory: there, against Law and Justice, and all Tyes of Friendship, and of Partnership betwixt us, you did conspire to seise upon the Fort, to Murther this our Worthy Governor; and by the help of your Plantations near, of Iacatra, and Banda, and Loho, to keep it for your selves.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: What proofs have you of this?

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: The confession of two Iaponneses hir'd by you to attempt it.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: I hear they have been forc'd by Torture to it.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: It matters not which way the truth come out; take heed, for their Example is before you.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Ye have no right, ye dare not Torture us, we owe you no subjection.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: That Sir, must be disputed at the Hague; in the mean time we are in possession here.

sp.speaker: 2 Dutch.
sp.p: And we can make our selves to be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Van Her.
sp.p: In few words Gentlemen confess. There is a Beverage ready for you else, which you'l not like to swallow.

sp.speaker: Collins:
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You shall be muffl'd up like Ladies, with an Oyl'd Cloath put underneath your Chins, then Water pour'd above; which either you must drink or must not breath.

sp.speaker: 1 Dutch:
sp.p: That's one way, we have others.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes, we have two Elements at your Service, Fire, as well as Water; certain things call'd Matches to be ty'd to your Fingers ends, which are as soveraign as Nutmegs, to quicken your short Memories.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: You are inhumane, to make your Cruelty your Pastime; Nature made me a Man, and not a Whale, to swallow down a flood.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You'l grow a Corpulent Gentleman like me; I shall love you the better for't, now you are but a spare rib.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: These things are only offer'd to your choice; you may avoid your Tortures and confess.

sp.speaker: Collins:
sp.p: Kill us first, for that we know is your design at last; and 'tis more Mercy now.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Be kind, and, Execute us, while we bare the shapes of Men, e're Fire and Water have destroy'd our Figures; let me go whole out of the World, I care not; and find my Body when I rise again so, as I need not be asham'd on't.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: 'Tis well you're Merry; will you yet confess?

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Bear e'm away to Torture.

sp.speaker: Van Her.
sp.p: Wee'l try your Constancy.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Wee'l shame your Cruelty; if we deserve our Tortures, 'tis first for freeing such an infamous Nation, that ought to have been slaves, and then for trusting them as Partners, who had cast off the Yoke of their lawful Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Away, I'le hear no more, now who comes the next?

div.stage: Exeunt the English with a Guard.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Towerson's Page, a Ship Boy, and a Woman.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Call e'm in. Exit a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Van-Her.
sp.p: We shall have easie work with them.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Not so easie as you imagine, they have indur'd the Beverage already; all Master of their pain, no one confessing.
the Devill's in these English, those brave Boys wou'd prove stout Topers if they liv'd.
sp.stage: Enter two Boyes and a Woman led as from Torture.
sp.p: Come hither ye perverse Imps, they say, you have indur'd the Water Torment, Wee'l try what Fire will do with you: you Sirrah, confess, were not you knowing of Towersons Plot, against this Fort and Island.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I have told your Hangman no, twelve times within this hour; when I was at the last Gaspe, and that's a time I think, when a Man shou'd not dissemble.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A Man, mark you that now; you English Boys have learn't a trick of late, of growing Men betimes, and doing Mens Work too, before you come to twenty.

sp.speaker: Van. Her.
sp.p: Sirrah, I will try if you are a Salamander, and can live i'th' Fire.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sure you think my Father got me of some Dutch Woman, and that I am but of a half straine courage; but you shall find that I am all o're English, as well in Fire as Water.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: Well of all Religions, I do not like your Dutch.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: No, and why young stripling.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: Because your Pennance comes before Confession.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Do you mock us Sirrah, to the Fire with him.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p: Do so, all you shall get by it, is this; before I answered no, now I'le be sullen and will talk no more.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Best cutting off these little Rogues betime, if they grow Men, they'le have the Spirit of Revenge in e'm.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes, as your Children have that of Rebellion; Oh that I cou'd but live to be Governor here, to make your fat Guts pledge me in that Beverage I drunk, you Sir Iohn Falstaff of Amsterdam.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: I have a little Brother in England, that I intend to appear to, when you have kill'd me; and if he do's not promise me the Death of ten Dutchmen in the next War, I'le haunt him instead of you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What say you Woman? have compassion of your self, and confess; you are of a softer Sex.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: But of a Courage full as Manly; there is no Sex in Souls; wou'd you have English Wives shew less of Bravery then their Children do? to lie by an English Man's side, is enough to give a Woman Resolution.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Here's a Hen of the Game too, but we shall tame you in the fire.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: My Innocence shall there be try'd like Gold, till it come out the purer. When you have burnt me all into one Wound, cram Gunpowder into 't, and blow me up, I'le not confess one word to shame my Countrey.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I think we have got here the Mother of the Maccabees; away with them all three. Exeunt the English Guarded. I'le take the pains my self to see these Tortur'd.

div.stage: Exeunt Harman, Van Herring, and the two Dutchmen with the English: manet Fiscal.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Oh you have ruin'd me, you have undone me, in the Person of my Husband!

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: If he will needs forfeit his Life to the Laws, by joyning with the English in a Plot, 'tis not in me to save him; but dearest Iulia be satisfy'd, you shall not want a Husband.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Do you think, I'le ever come into a Bed with him, who rob'd me of my dear sweet Man?

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Dry up your Tears, I'me in earnest, I will Marry you, yfaith I will; it is your destiny.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Nay if it be my Destiny: but I vow I'le ne're be yours but upon one condition.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Name your desire and take it.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Then save poor Beamonts Life.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: This is the most unkind Request you cou'd have made, it shews you Love him better: therefore in prudence I shou'd hast his Death.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Come, I'le not be deny'd, you shall give me his Life, or I'le not love you, by this Kiss you shall Child;

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Pray ask some other thing.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: I have your word for this, and if you break it, how shall I trust you for your Marrying me.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Well, I will do't to oblige you. aside.
But to prevent her new designs with him, I'le see him shipt away for England straight.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: I may build upon your promise then:

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Most firmly: I hear company.

div.stage: Enter Harman, Van Herring, and the two Dutchmen with Towerson Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Now Captain Towerson you have had the Priviledge to be examin'd last: this on the score of my old Friendship with you, though you have ill deserv'd it. But here you stand accus'd of no less Crimes then Robbery first, then Murther, and last Treason: what can you say to clear your self?

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: You're interested in all, and therefore partial; I have consider'd on't, and will not plead, because I know you have no right to judge me: for the last Treaty 'twixt our King and you expresly said, that causes Criminal were first to be Examin'd, and then Judg'd, not here, but by the Councel of Defence; to whom I make Appeal.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: This Court conceives that it has power to judge you; deriv'd from the most High and Mighty States, who in this Island are Supream, and that as well in Criminal, as Civil Causes.

sp.speaker: 1 Dutchman.
sp.p: You are not to question the Authority of the Court which is to Judge you.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Sir, by your favor, I both must, and will: I'le not so far betray my Nations right; we are not here your Subjects, but your Partners: and that Supremacy of power you claim, extends but to the Natives, not to us: dare you, who in the British Seas strike Sayl, nay more, whose Lives and Freedome are our Alms, presume to sit and judge your Benefactors. Your base new upstart Common-Wealth shou'd blush, to doom the Subjects of an English King, the meanest of whose Merchants wou'd disdain the narrow life, and the Domestick baseness of one of those you call your mighty States.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: You spend your Breath in Rayling; speak to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Hold yet: because you shall not call us cruel, or plead I wou'd be judge in my own cause; I shall accept of that appeal you make, concerning my Sons death; provided first you clear your self from what concerns the publick; for that relating to our general safety, the judgment of it cannot be deferr'd; but with our common danger.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Let me first be bold to question you: what circumstance can make this your pretended Plot seem likely? the Natives first you tortur'd, their confession Extorted so, can prove no crime in us. Consider next the strength of this your Castle; it's Garrison above two hundred Men, besides as many of your City Burgers, all ready on the least Allarme, or Summons, to Reinforce the others, for ten English, and Merchants they, not Souldiers, with the Ayd of ten Iapanners; all of e'm unarm'd, except five Swords, and not so many Muskets; th' attempt had only been for Fools or Madmen.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: We cannot help your want of Wit; proceed.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Grant then we had been desperate enough to hazard this; we must at least forecast how to secure possession when we had it. We had no Ship nor Pinnace in the Harbor; nor cou'd have Aid from any Factory: the nearest to us forty Leagues from hence, and they but few in number: you besides this Fort, have yet three Castles in this Isle amply provided for, and eight tall Ships riding at Anchor near; considering this, and think what all the World will judge of it.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Nothing but Falshood is to be expected from such a Tongue, whose Heart is foul'd with Treason. Give him the Beverage.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: 'Tis ready Sir.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Hold; I have some reluctance to proceed to that extremity: he was my Friend, and I wou'd have him franckly to confess: push ope that Prison door, and set before him the image of his pains in other Men.

stage.hi: The Scene opens, and discovers the English Tortur'd, and the Dutch tormenting them.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Now Sir, how does the Object like you?

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Are you Men or Devils! D'Alva, whom you condemn for cruelty did ne're the like; he knew original Villany was in your Blood: your Fathers all are damn'd for their Rebellion; when they Rebell'd, they were well us'd to this: these Tortures ne're were hatch'd in Humane Breasts, but as your Countrey lies confin'd on Hell, just on its Marches, your black Neighbors taught ye, and just such pains as you invent on Earth, Hell has reserv'd for you.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Are you yet mov'd?

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: But not as you wou'd have me. I could weep tears of Blood to view this usage; but you, as if not made of the same Mould, see with dry eyes the Miseries of Men, as they were Creatures of another kind, not Christians, nor Allies, nor Partners with you, but as if Beasts, transfix'd on Theatres, to make you cruel sport.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: These are but vulgar Objects, bring his Friend; let him behold his Tortures; shut that door. The Scene clos'd.

div.stage: Enter Beamont led, with Matches ty'd to his Hands.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: embracing him. Oh my dear friend, now I am truly wretched! even in that part which is most sensible, my friendship: how have we liv'd to see the English name, the scorn of these, the vilest of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Courage my friend, and rather praise we Heaven, that it has chose two such as you and me, who will not shame our Countrey with our pains, but stand like Marble Statues in their fires, scorch'd and defac'd perhaps, not melted down. So let 'em burn this Tenement of Earth; they can but burn me naked to my soul▪ that's of a Nobler frame, and will stand Firme, Upright, and Unconsum'd.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Confess; if you have kindness, save your friend.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Yes, by my death I wou'd, not by my confession; he is so brave, he wou'd not so be sav'd; but wou'd renounce a friendship built on shame.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Bring more Candles, and burn him from the Wrists up to the Elbows.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Do, I'le enjoy the Flames like Scaevola; and when one's roasted, give the other hand.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Let me embrace you while you are a Man, now you must lose that form; be parch'd and rivel'd like a dry'd Mummy, or dead Malefactor, expos'd in Chains, and blown about by Winds.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Yet this I can endure, Go on, and weary out two Elements; Vex Fire and Water with th' Experiments of pains far worse then death.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Oh let me take my turn; you will have double pleasure, I'm asham'd to be the only Englishman untortur'd.

sp.speaker: Van Her.
sp.p: You soon shou'd have your wish; but that we know in him you suffer more.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Fill me a brim full Glass: now Captain, here's to all your Countreymen; I wish your whole East India Company were in this room, that we might use them thus.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: They shou'd have Fires of Cloves and Cinamon, we wou'd cut down whole Groves to Honour 'em, and be at cost to burn 'em nobly.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Barb'rous Villains! now you show your selves.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Boy, take that Candle thence, and bring it hither, I am exalted, and wou'd light my Pipe just where the Wyck is fed with English Fat.

sp.speaker: Van Her.
sp.p: So wou'd I; oh the Tobacco tasts Divinely after it.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: We have friends in England who wou'd weep to see this acted on a Theatre, which here you make your pastime.

sp.speaker: Boam.
sp.p: Oh that this Flesh were turn'd a cake of Ice, that I might in an instant melt away, and become nothing, to escape this Torment, there is not cold enough in all the North to quench my burning blood.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Do with Beamont as you please, so Towerson dye.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: You'l not confess yet Captain?

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Hangman, no. I wou'd have don't before, if e're I wou'd: to do it when my friend has suffer'd this, were to be less then he.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Free him. To Beamont aside.

sp.speaker: Beamont
sp.p: I have not sworn you shou'd not suffer, but that you shou'd not dye; thank Iulia for't, but on your life do not delay this hour to post from hence; so to your next Plantation; I cannot suffer a lov'd Rival near me.

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: I almost question if I will receive my life from thee: 'tis like a cure from Witches; 'twill leave a sin behind it.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Nay, I'm not lavish of my courtesie; I can on easy terms resume my gift.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Captain, you're a dead man; I'le spare your torture for your Quality; prepare for execution instantly.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: I am prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: You dye in charity I hope.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: I can forgive even thee; my innocence I need not name, you know it. One farewel kiss of my dear Ysabinda, and all my business here on earth is done.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Call her, she's at the door. Exit Fiscal.

sp.speaker: Towes.
sp.p: to Beam. embracing. A long and last farewel; I take my death with the more chearfulness because thou liv'st behind me: tell my friends I dy'd so as became a Christian and a Man; give to my brave Employers of the East India Company, the last remembrance of my faithful service; tell 'em I Seal that Service with my Blood; and dying, wish to all their Factories, and all the famous Merchants of our Isle, that Wealth their gen'rous Industry deserves; but dare not hope it with Dutch partnership. Last, there's my heart, I give it in this kiss— Kisses him. Do not answer me; Friendship's a tender thing, and it would ill become me now to weep.—

sp.speaker: Beam.
sp.p: Adieu, if I wou'd speak, I cannot.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Is it permitted me to see your Eies once more, before Eternal night shall close 'em.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: I summon'd all I had of Man to see you, 'twas well the time allow'd for it, was short, I cou'd not bear it long: 'tis dangerous, and would divide my Love 'twixt Heaven and you. I therefore part in haste; think I am going a suddain journey, and have not the leisure to take a ceremonious long farewel.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Do you still love me?

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: Do not suppose I do, 'tis for your ease, since you must stay behind me; to think I was unkind, you'l grieve the less!

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: Though I suspect you joyn'd in my Sons Murder, yet since it is not prov'd, you have your life.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: I thank you for't, I'le make the noblest use of your sad gift; that is, to dye unforc'd; I'le make a present of my life to Towerson; to let you see, though worthless of his Love, I would not live without him.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: I charge you love my memory, but live.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: She shall be strictly guarded from that violence, she means against her self.

sp.speaker: Ysab.
sp.p: Vain Men! there are so many paths to death, you cannot stop 'em all; o're the green Turf where my Love's laid, there will I mourning sit, and draw no air but from the damps that rise out of that hallow'd Earth; and for my Dyet, I mean my Eies alone shall feed my Mouth. Thus will I live, till he in pity rise, and the pale shrowd take me in his cold Arms, and lay me kindly by him in his Grave,

div.stage: Enter Collins, and then Perez, Julia following him.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: No more; your time's now come, you must away.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Now Devils; you have done your worst with tortures, Death's a privation of pain; but they were a continual dying,

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Farewel my dearest, I may have many Husbands, but never one like thee.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p:
As you love my Soul, take hence that Woman; my English friends, I'm not asham'd of death, while I have you for part'ners; I know you innocent, and so am I, of this
pretended plot; but I am guilty of a greater crime; For, being married in another Countrey: the Governors perswasions, and my love to that ill Woman, made me leave the first, and make this fatal choice. I'm justly punish'd, for her sake I dye; the Fiscal to enjoy her has accus'd me. There is another cause— by his procurement I shou'd have kill'd.—

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Away with him, and stop his mouth. He is led off.

sp.speaker: Towers.
sp.p: I leave thee Life with no regret at parting, full of whatever thou cou'dst give, I rise from thy neglected Feast, and go to sleep: yet on this brink of death, my Eies are open'd, and Heav'n has bid me prophesy to you th' unjust contrivers of this Tragick Scene; An Age is coming, when an English Monarch with Blood, shall pay that blood which you have shed: to save your Cities from victorious Arms, you shall invite the Waves to hide your Earth, and trembling to the tops of Houses fly, while Deluges invade your lower rooms: Then, as with Waters you have swell'd our Bodies, with damps of Waters shall your Heads be swoln;
sp.l: Till at the last your sap'd foundations fall,

div.stage: He's led out with the English; the Dutch remain.

sp.speaker: Van Her.
sp.p: Ay, ay, we'l venture both our Selves, and Children for such another pull.

sp.speaker: 1. Dutch.
sp.p: Let him prophesy when his Head's off.

sp.speaker: 2. Dutch.
sp.p: There's ne'r a Nostradamus of 'em all shall fright us from our gain.

sp.speaker: Fisc.
sp.p: Now for a smooth Apology, and then a fawning Letter to the King of England; and our work's done.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.p: 'Tis done as I wou'd wish it. Now Brethren, at my proper cost and charges, three days you are my Guests; in which good time we will divide their greatest Wealth by Lots, while wantonly we rifle for the rest:
sp.l: Then in full Romers, and with joyful Hearts
We'l drink confusion to all English Starts Exeunt.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: A Poet once the Spartan's led to fight,
And made 'em Conquer in the Muses right:
So wou'd our Poet lead you on this day:
Showing your tortur'd Fathers in his Play.
To one well born, th' affront is worse and more,
When he's abus'd, and baffled by a Bore:
With an ill Grace the Dutch their mischiefs do,
They've both ill Nature and ill Manners too.
Well may they boast themselves an antient Nation,
For they were bred e're Manners, were in fashion:
And their new Common wealth has set 'em free,
Onely from Honour and Civility.
Venetians do not more uncouthly ride,
Than did their Lubber-State Mankind bestride.
Their sway became 'em with as ill a Meen,
As their own Paunches swell above their Chin:
Yet is their Empire no true Growth but Humour,
And onely two King's Touch can cure the Tumor.
As Cato did his Affricque Fruits display:
So we before your Eies their Indies lay:
All Loyal English will like him conclude,
Let Caesar Live, and Carthage be subdu'd.
